projectDesc.p: "憶王孫" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the Tune “Yearning for the Prince”
Wind comes from the lake; waves are misty and grand.
The autumn is late; the reds are rare and fragrance faint.
The water radiance and mountain colors are befriending me.
One cannot talk enough about their endless beauty.
The lotus seeds are ripen and leaves old,
pure drew washes over the duckweed and water grass.
Gulls and egrets sleep on the sand, without turning their heads,
as if they resent me for returning too early.
